SALT LAKE CITY (AP) — An advertising-technology billionaire has formally resigned his membership in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and rebuked the faith over social issues and LGBTQ rights in an unusual public move. Jeff T. Green has pledged to donate 90% of his estimated $5 billion fortune, starting with a $600,000 donation to the LGBTQ-rights group Equality Utah, the Salt Lake Tribune reported. Green said in a Monday resignation letter to church President Russell M. Nelson that he hasn’t been active in the faith widely known as Mormon for more than a decade but wanted to make his departure official and remove his name from membership records. “I believe the Mormon church has hindered global progress in women’s rights, civil rights and racial equality, and LGBTQ+ rights,” he wrote. Eleven family members and a friend formally resigned along with him. The church didn’t immediately return a message from The Associated Press seeking comment Tuesday, but in recent years has shown a willingness to engage on LGBTQ rights that is unusual for a conservative faith. It maintains its doctrinal opposition to same-sex marriage and intimacy, but the faith didn’t block a 2019 ban on so-called conversion therapy in Utah and in November high-ranking leader Dallin Oaks called for a recognition of both religious rights and LGBTQ rights. Still, the church has taken positions over the years that have been deeply painful for many in the LGBTQ community. Green, for his part, said most church members “are good people trying to do right,” but he also worries about the faith’s transparency around its history and finances. Green, 44, now lives in Southern California. He is the CEO and chairman of The Trade Desk, an advertising-technology firm he founded in 2009. He also mentioned concerns about a $100 billion investment portfolio held by the faith. It was the subject of an Internal Revenue Service whistleblower complaint in 2019, from a former employee who charged the church had improperly built it up using member donations that are supposed to go to charitable causes. Leaders have defended how the church uses and invests member donations, saying most is used for operational and humanitarian needs, but a portion is safeguarded to build a reserve for the future. The faith annually spends about $1 billion on humanitarian and welfare aid, leaders have said. The church has also come under criticism for conservative social positions. Women do not hold the priesthood in the faith, and Black men could not until the 1970s. In recent years, though, the faith has worked with the NAACP and donated nearly $10 million for initiatives to help Black Americans. It has also worked with Equality Utah to pass a state LGBTQ nondiscrimination law, with religious exemptions. Another prominent onetime Latter-day Saint sued the faith this year, accusing it of fraud and seeking to recover millions of dollars in contributions. Founded in 1907 by members of two eastern Idaho pioneer families, the creamery once operated 12 locations from Salmon, Idaho, to Afton, Wyo., and Salt Lake City. The Ricks name alone should ring a bell with most Idahoans, because Thomas Ricks was the founding father of Rexburg. He also established the Bannock Stake Academy in 1888. It was renamed Ricks Academy in 1903 and became Ricks College, owned and operated by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints and then BYU-Idaho in 2001. The creamery moved its corporate office to Salt Lake City sometime before 1920. Early on, the firm concentrated on milk and butter. Over time, it shifted its business to focus on its Banquet brand of cheese. It closed or sold off its smaller locations as refrigeration and milk-hauling technology advanced. The firm built a new cheese plant just north of Rexburg, on the unincorporated edge of Sugar City in 1975, along the south channel of the Teton River. The sale included the www.banquetcheese.com website and a limited license to use of the Nelson-Ricks Creamery name. Mike and Mary Greenberg, owners of the Greenberg Cheese Company in Southern California, bought the Sugar City cheese plant and the Nelson-Ricks brand name in 2013. The Greenbergs incorporated the Nelson Ricks Cheese Company and restarted the plant by 2014. Mike Greenberg was the president and Mary the secretary of the corporation. In 2014, the cheese company sold the Nelson-Ricks Creamery brand name, along with the plant and its equipment, to a shell company the Greenbergs created called NRCC Asset Acquisition. At the same time, they terminated Lakeview’s limited license to use the Nelson-Ricks mark. In response, Lakeview updated the Banquet website to remove all links to “About Us” webpage that used the creamery’s name, but did not remove the page. In a July 2018 summary judgement, Judge David Nye of the U.S. District Court, Idaho Division, ruled against NRCC, finding that Lakeview had not used the mark in commerce and therefore had not infringed on the mark. In August 2019, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the award of attorney fees to Lakeview. NRCC immediately filed a motion for rehearing, which was subsequently denied.
